conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the heat transferred by the gas during the process from state A to state C using the first law of thermodynamics and the properties of ideal gases.
State A: \( P_A = 3 \times 10^5 \) Pa, \( V_A = 2 \times 10^{-3} \) m³, \( T_A = 27^\circ \text{C} = 300 \) K
State B: \( P_B = 2 \times 10^5 \) Pa, \( V_B = 2 \times 10^{-3} \) m³
State C: \( P_C = 2 \times 10^5 \) Pa, \( V_C = 3 \times 10^{-3} \) m³

premise: Using the ideal gas law \( PV = nRT \) for state A: \( 3 \times 10^5 \times 2 \times 10^{-3} = n R \times 300 \)
Using the ideal gas law for state B: \( 2 \times 10^5 \times 2 \times 10^{-3} = 2 \times T_B \)
Using the ideal gas law for state C: \( 2 \times 10^5 \times 3 \times 10^{-3} = 2 \times T_C \)
Process A to B is isochoric, so no work is done.
Work done during an isobaric process B to C: \( W_{BC} = P \Delta V \)
Total work done from A to C: \( W_{AC} = W_{AB} + W_{BC} \)
Change in internal energy from A to B: \( \Delta U_{AB} = n C_V (T_B - T_A) \)
Change in internal energy from B to C: \( \Delta U_{BC} = n C_V (T_C - T_B) \)
Total change in internal energy from A to C: \( \Delta U_{AC} = \Delta U_{AB} + \Delta U_{BC} \)
First law of thermodynamics: \( Q = \Delta U + W \)
